abstract.text: Set up your app’s life cycle and create its user interface with SwiftUI.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Develop powerful, personal apps for Apple Watch using SwiftUI, a declarative
framework for building user interfaces on all of Apple’s platforms. You can
create rich user interfaces by composing simple views — which perform a single,
focused task — into larger, more complex layouts. Your app describes the correct
layout for its views based on its current state. SwiftUI detects changes to the
state and updates the views accordingly.
On watchOS, SwiftUI gives you considerably more freedom, power, and control than
user interfaces laid out and designed in a storyboard. For example,
the platter style, swipe actions (shown below), and row reordering.
Additionally, you can preview your SwiftUI code in Xcode’s canvas. You can
design, build, and test your interfaces without ever running your app.
SwiftUI also provides watch-specific representations of tab and navigation
views, with fully customizable navigation bars and customizable toolbar items
for confirmation, cancellation, and destructive actions. You can also use
SwiftUI to manage your app’s life cycle. To learn more about SwiftUI, see
To manage your app’s life cycle with SwiftUI, create a structure that adopts the
attribute indicates this is the entry point for your app. Each app can have only

provides a navigation stack and title
When your app launches, it displays the view hierarchy defined by the window
You can also add scenes for notification categories.
When the system receives a notification with a matching category, it displays
a dynamic view specified by the notification controller. You can create
subclass for each notification category supported by your app.

abstract.text: A type that represents the structure and behavior of an app.
The content and behavior of the app.
The kinds of background tasks that your app or extension can handle.
The current phase of the scene.
A container that presents rows of data arranged in a single column, optionally providing the ability to select one or more members.
A view for presenting a stack of views that represents a visible path in a navigation hierarchy.
A part of an app’s user interface with a life cycle managed by the system.
Runs the specified action when the system provides a background task.
Adds an action to perform when the given value changes.
Registers a handler to invoke in response to a user activity that your app receives.
A property wrapper that is used in `App` to provide a delegate from WatchKit.
A WatchKit user notification interface controller that hosts a SwiftUI view hierarchy.
A scene that presents a group of identically structured windows.
Learn about important changes to watchOS.
A collection of methods that manages the app-level behavior for a single-target watchOS app.
Tells the delegate that the launch process is almost done and the app is almost ready to run.
An object that creates and manages the contents of a single-column table interface.
Detect and respond to common state transitions.
Detect and respond to user activity information from Handoff or a complication.
Receive and respond to life-cycle notifications.
Handle scheduled update tasks in the background, and respond to background system interactions including Siri intents and incoming Bluetooth messages.
A representation of the state of your app at a moment in time.
SwiftUI is a modern way to declare user interfaces for any Apple platform. Create beautiful, dynamic apps faster than ever before.
This tutorial gives you a chance to apply much of what you’ve already learned about SwiftUI, and — with little effort — migrate the Landmarks app to watchOS.
Build watchOS apps that combine complications, notifications, and Siri to create
a personal experience on Apple Watch.
Provide an even more streamlined, consistent, and glanceable user experience with new design features.

doc://com.apple.watchOS-Apps/documentati.title: Creating an intuitive and effective UI in watchOS 10

abstract.text: Create custom interfaces for your watchOS app’s notifications.
Integrate SwiftUI elements and watch-specific features, and build widgets for the Smart Stack.
